A plan to turn the River Thames into a park has been devised that would involve the construction of a new bridge and the reopening in 2021 of part of the original Thames Embankment. The reopening would coincide with the UK’s European Union withdrawal date of March 29, 2021.The reorganization plan was drawn up in conjunction with the UK’s request for $14.7 billion for the 2019–20 financial year, a cut from the £16.7 billion requested for 2020. It would also see some of the riverfront land converted into artist’s studios and other spaces that could be restored to their original state with further restoration work set to begin in the spring of 2021.“This is a moment of great change for the UK and we are working hard to make the most of it,” said Culture Secretary Justine Greening. “This is a project for all of us and I am proud that I have been able to work with the British Institute and Peter to develop and deliver such a wonderful project for Londoners.”
